Graphical abstract By introducing ethylene glycol into aqueous LiCl solution, high-voltage and anti-freezing electrolyte with low cost and high ionic conductivity is developed for aqueous planar micro-supercapacitors, with high voltage, enhanced energy density and excellent low-temperature stability. Micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) are considered as highly competitive power sources for miniaturized electronics. However, narrow voltage window and poor anti-freezing properties of MSCs in conventional aqueous electrolytes lead to low energy density and limited environmental adaption. Herein, we report the construction of low-temperature and high-energy-density MSCs based on anti-freezing hybrid gel electrolytes (HGE) through introducing ethylene glycol (EG) additives into aqueous LiCl electrolyte. Since EG partially destroys hydrogen bond network among water molecules, the HGE exhibits maximum electrochemical stability window of 2.7 V and superior anti-freezing features with a glass transition temperature of −62.8 °C. Further, the optimized MSCs using activated carbon microelectrodes possess impressive volumetric capacitance of 28.9 F cm−3 and energy density of 10.3 mWh cm−3 in the voltage of 1.6 V, 2.6 times higher than MSCs tested in 1.2 V. Importantly, the MSCs display 68.3% capacitance retention even at −30 °C compared to the value at 25 °C, and ultra-long cyclability with 85.7% of initial capacitance after 15,000 times, indicating extraordinary low-temperature performance. Besides, our devices offer favorable flexibility and modular integration. Therefore, this work provides a general strategy of realizing flexible, safe and anti-freezing microscale power sources, holding great potential towards subzero-temperature microelectronic applications. Keywords Hybrid gel electrolyte Micro-supercapacitors Low temperature High voltage Graphene 1 Introduction With the rapid growth of modern technology, the new-concept, flexible and intelligent microelectronics have gradually emerged on the market, including foldable mobile phones, smart watches and patchable medical devices [1–4], which has put forward urgent demand for microscale energy storage devices with excellent performance and matched properties. Among them, micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) have attracted wide attentions as one class of competitive miniaturized power sources, due to notable advantages such as small size, favorable mechanical robustness, high power density, short charge time and long service life [5–7]. Therefore, researchers have devoted huge efforts in exploration of MSCs and great progress have been achieved in various aspects of electrode materials, device structure, microfabrication techniques, functional characteristics and system integration [8–10]. Despite of excellent advancements, the wide application of MSCs is still limited by low energy density and poor adaptation to extreme environment, both of which are directly related to physicochemical properties of electrolytes. The energy density of MSCs is proportionable to the square of the cell voltage [11–13]. As a result, the conventional aqueous electrolytes have gradually become a bottleneck in enhancement of energy density considering their low electrochemical stability window (decomposition voltage of pure water is 1.23 V) [14,15]. Furthermore, common aqueous electrolytes would freeze at their freezing temperatures, causing a sharp performance degradation and thereby hindering operation of MSCs in low-temperature environments [16,17]. Although organic electrolytes and ionic liquids generally exhibit wide voltage window (even up to 4 V), intrinsic toxicity and flammability of organic electrolytes usually give rise to safe and environmental concerns [18,19], and high viscosity and low conductivity of ionic liquids would result in inferior rate performance of MSCs especially at low temperature [20–22], all of which call for reasonable design and optimization in electrolyte. Recently, high-concentration water-in-salt (WIS) electrolytes have been explored to successfully broaden the voltage window of aqueous electrolyte to 3 V by virtue of strong coordination between water molecules and ions [23,24], showing great application prospect in high-voltage and inherently safe MSCs. Nevertheless, large-amount usage of salt in high-concentration (or even saturated) WIS electrolyte significantly increases the cost. Besides, the possible salt precipitation in WIS electrolyte at low temperature would also impede operation of MSCs in wide temperature range [24,25]. In addition, the freezing point of the electrolyte can also be reduced by introducing an organic solvent into the aqueous solution. Typically, by introducing ethylene glycol (EG) solvent into aqueous electrolyte, supercapacitors can work normally at −20 °C [26,27]. However, the operating voltage of low-temperature supercapacitors reported was still very limited. Therefore, it is highly desired to exploit new strategies to realize high-voltage and low-temperature electrolytes for constructions of practical MSCs. Herein, we have developed a hybrid gel electrolyte (HGE) of 10 M LiCl dissolved in mixture solvent of water and EG with adjustable volume ratios, for construction of high-voltage and low-temperature MSCs. Because the introduction of EG effectively destroyed hydrogen bond network inside water molecules, the HGE delivered higher electrochemical stability window of up to 2.7 V and lower glass-transition temperature (−62.8 °C) compared to 10 M LiCl electrolyte in pure water. Based on HGE with optimal ratio, the planar MSCs using activated carbon (AC) electrodes and high-conductivity few-layer graphene (FLG) current collectors fabricated by mask-assisted vacuum filtration strategy exhibited a high voltage of 1.6 V and a volumetric energy density of 10.3 mWh cm−3, 2.6 times higher than MSCs tested in a cell voltage of 1.2 V. More importantly, our devices displayed high capacitance retention of 68.3% even at an ultralow temperature of −30 °C in comparison to room temperature and excellent cycle stability at low temperature (−20 and −30 °C). In addition, the MSCs also showed favorable mechanical flexibility and performance customization through serial/parallel connection of multiple cells, suggestive of outstanding practicability of the obtained MSCs towards wearable situations in various regions with different climates. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials preparation The AC (C196580) was purchased form Aladdin. The high-conductivity FLG nanosheets were prepared by the electrochemical exfoliation of graphite paper (0.13 mm, carbon content: 99.8%, Alfa Aesar) in 7 M KOH (Kermel, AR) aqueous solution, according to the previous work [28]. Typically, a graphite paper was used as cathode (working electrode), and a platinum mesh electrode was used as anode (counter electrode). The graphite paper was exfoliated for 2 h at a voltage of 10 V and a current of 4.0 A. After completing the exfoliation, the product was rinsed with deionized water several times until the pH is about 7.0. Finally, the resultant FLG was dispersed in ethanol (Kermel, AR) solution under strong sonication with a power of 200 W for 45 min for subsequent usage. 2.2 Hybrid gel electrolytes First, 4.239 g of anhydrous lithium chloride (LiCl, Kermel, AR) was dissolved into 10 mL of EG (Sinopharm, AR)-water binary solvent to obtain an electrolyte with a LiCl salt concentration of 10 M. In the mixed solution, the volume fraction of EG in the solution gradually increased from 0% to 20%, 40%, 50%, and 60%. Then, 1 g of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA, molecular weight ∼205,000, Aladdin) was added to the above electrolyte and the solution was further stirred at 90 °C for 10 h to obtain a uniform gel electrolyte. The relevant electrolytes were marked as EG0, EG2, EG4, EG5, and EG6, respectively. 2.3 Fabrication of MSCs First, 2 mL stable FLG dispersion (0.1 mg mL−1 in ethanol) was filtrated on a nylon membrane (0.22 μm pore size), with the help of a customized interdigital mask (8 fingers, 14 mm in length, 1 mm in width, and 0.5 mm width of interspacing). Then, 2 mL AC and FLG mixture dispersion (0.2 mg mL−1 in ethanol, AC: FLG mass ratio of 9:1) was added to the positive and negative sides (four fingers) of the interdigital mask. Subsequently, 2 mL FLG dispersion (0.02 mg mL−1 in ethanol) was filtered on the top of AC electrodes. After removing the mask and naturally drying at room temperature for 12 h, the thin-film microelectrodes with a planar interdigital pattern were obtained. Afterwards, the gel electrolyte was carefully applied onto the interdigital microelectrodes. Finally, planar MSCs were achieved after Kapton tape package. The FLG-MSCs microelectrodes were made by filtering 2 mL stable FLG dispersion (0.5 mg mL−1 in ethanol) on the nylon membrane, drying at room temperature for 12 h, coating with EG5 gel electrolyte, and encapsulating to obtain FLG-MSCs-5. 2.4 Materials characterizations The apparent viscosity of the electrolyte at 25 °C can be obtained with rotational viscosity test with a rotary rheometer RHE DHR2 at a shear rate of 100 s−1 (TA Instruments-Waters LLC). The Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) tests were examined by Nicolet iS50, thermofisher. Each spectrum was recorded at a rate of 32 scans with a resolution of 4 cm−1, collected from 1111 to 4000 cm−1 in transmission mode. A liquid solution of 5 μL was tested via a CaF2 cell sealed with screws. Raman spectra was recorded using Raman spectrometer (LabRAM HR 800) equipped with a green laser emitting at 532 nm and a 50x lens. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm was performed on a porosimeter (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020). The sample was degassed at 300 °C for 6 h prior to the measurement. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was performed using JSM-7900F. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was performed using HT7700. 2.5 Electrochemical test The ionic conductivity (σ) of the HGE was measured at different temperatures through electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) at the frequency from 100 kHz to 0.1 Hz with an ac amplitude of 5 mV, based on a cell of stainless steel/HGE/stainless steel. The electrolyte resistance was acquired from the intercept of Nyquist plot and the ionic conductivity was calculated according to the following equation, σ = L R s A where L is the thickness of the hybrid gel electrolyte (the distance between stainless steel and stainless steel), R s is the electrolyte resistance from EIS, and A is the geometric area of the stainless steel electrode [29]. The electrochemical performances were performed by electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). CV curves were tested at scan rates from 5 to 300 mV s−1. GCD profiles were tested at different current densities ranging from 0.1 to 1 mA cm−2. The volumetric capacitiance and energy density in this work were calculated based on two electrodes. Cycling stability was carried out at current densities of 0.5, 1.0 or 1.5 mA cm−2. Low-temperature performance measurement of MSCs at 10 to −30 °C was carried out after keeping the device at tested temperature for 2 h until equilibration. Before self-discharge measurement, the MSCs were activated by charging and discharging for ten times. After that, the MSCs were charged with a constant current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 to reach the cut-off voltage (1.2 or 1.6 V), and then the self-discharge process was observed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication of low-temperature planar MSCs The MSCs were fabricated by mask-assisted vacuum filtration strategy [30], as illustrated in Fig. 1 (a). Firstly, the high-conductivity FLG nanosheets (Figs. 1b and Fig. S1) were prepared by electrochemical cathodic exfoliation [28], and the metal-free current collectors were prepared by directly filtering dispersion of FLG on the nylon membrane with assistance of an interdigital mask. Then, the mixture of AC microelectrode materials and FLG conductive additives was sequentially deposited on the FLG current collectors by similar filtration step. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images of the AC material after ultrasonic treatment were shown in Fig. 1(c), and most of AC particle sizes were less than 4 μm. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm of AC (Fig. S2a) clearly showed the Type I curve [31,32], indicating that the AC possessed microporous nature. Specifically, the pore size distribution of the AC was concentrated at ∼1.94 nm, and its specific surface area is about 2069 m2 g−1 (Fig. S2b). Further, another layer of FLG nanosheets was deposited onto active materials to improve conductivity. In such layer-by-layer stacked electrode structure, the middle FLG nanosheets thoroughly interpenetrated into the AC microelectrode contributed to close connections with the FLG film at the bottom and the top layers to form a highly conductive network, leading to superior charge transport. It is observed that the microelectrode showed a flat surface and a typical thickness of 4.2 μm (Fig. 1d and e). Meanwhile, there was no any structural fracture or delamination under a variety of mechanical deformation, indicating excellent structural stability of the MSCs (Fig. 1f−i). Finally, the MSCs were achieved after carefully cast-coating HGE onto the project area of microelectrodes and encapsulating it with Kapton tapes (see details in experimental section). 3.2 Characterizations of hybrid gel electrolytes As mentioned above, the performance of MSCs is largely dependent on features of electrolyte. Therefore, a series of HGEs with 10 M LiCl, in which the EG-to-solution volume ratio was set from 0% to 20%, 40%, 50%, and 60%, were prepared and corresponding electrolytes were marked as EG0, EG2, EG4, EG5, and EG6, respectively, to discuss the effect of EG content on HGE. First, the stable electrochemical window of the HGE was investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) using Pt/C electrode as a working electrode, Pt electrode as a counter electrode and Ag/AgCl as a reference electrode (Fig. 2 a). It was observable that when the volume fraction of EG increased to 50%, the electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte has been significantly broadened to ∼2.7 V (−1.5 to 1.2 V vs. Ag/AgCl), indicating the effective impact of EG additives on enhancement in potential window of the HGEs. This was also demonstrated by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of MSCs tested in different electrolytes in a voltage window of 0–1.6 V at a scan rate of 300 mV s−1 (Fig. 2b and Fig. S3). Although it could be seen that all of them present nearly rectangular shapes, the CV curves of MSCs using EG0, EG2 and EG4 as electrolytes revealed obvious polarization phenomenon, which was not observed in MSCs using EG5 and EG6 electrolytes. In addition, the rheological measurements at room temperature (Fig. 2c) reflected that the viscosity of the electrolyte would gradually increase with the increase of EG content, which may affect the diffusion of ions in the electrolyte, further leading to the decrease of ionic conductivity of the electrolyte (Fig. 2d). The ionic conductivity of EG5 at room temperature was 17 mS cm−1, higher than recently reported gel electrolytes such as 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(fluorosulfonyl)imide (EMIFSI)/SiO2 gel electrolyte (1.99 mS cm−1) [13], KOH-PVA-KI gel electrolyte (12.73 mS cm−1) [14], and zinc trifluoromethanesulfonate (Zn(Tf)2)/EG/PVA (15.03 mS cm−1) [15]. Moreover, the ionic conductivity tests of various electrolytes were conducted at different temperatures by EIS (Figs. S4 and S5). As shown in Fig. 2(e), at the temperature of 10 and 0 °C, the EG0 gave out a higher ionic conductivity than the HGEs with EG additives. However, when the temperature dropped to −10 °C, the ion conductivity of EG0 exhibited a rapid decline, and all the electrolytes with EG added (except EG6) all showed higher ionic conductivity than EG0. In particular, the EG5 could still maintain high ionic conductivity of 0.83 mS cm−1 at −40 °C, equivalent to 8 times the conductivity of EG0, displaying great potential of EG additives in improving anti-freezing performance of HGEs. To expound the mechanism of EG additives for enhancement of voltage window and temperature applicability of HGEs, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) and Raman spectra were carried out and characterization results are displayed in Fig. 2(f and g). It is found that with the increase of EG content, the stretching vibration of OH shifts to lower wavenumber at 3000–3500 cm−1 [33], and the bending vibration of H2O shifts to higher wavenumbers at 1600–1700 cm−1 [34], indicating the reduction of free water molecules and formation of hydrogen bond between EG and water molecules in the hybrid electrolyte [35]. At the same time, two representative absorption peaks at 2840–2990 cm−1 corresponding to the symmetric CH stretching shift to lower wavenumbers [36], due to the redistribution of charge after the formation of hydrogen bonds between hydroxyl groups of EG and H2O molecules [37]. Taken together, it is suggested that the interaction between EG and H2O molecules can partially break the hydrogen bonding network among water molecules, hence reducing the freezing point and increasing the working voltage of HGEs [38], which was also demonstrated by Raman spectrum. Fig. 2g shows that the OH stretching in H2O molecules shifts to lower wavenumbers at 3200–3400 cm−1, the symmetric CH stretching shifts to lower wavenumbers at 2800–2900 cm−1 from EG2 to EG6 [39,40], and COH bending shifts to higher wavenumber at 1460–1470 cm−1 from EG0 to EG6, manifesting higher electron density of COH in EG than OH in H2O and further revealing the formation of hydrogen bond between H atoms in H2O and O atoms in EG, consistent with the FTIR results [41]. All of these prove that the introduction of EG can break the intramolecular hydrogen bond network among H2O molecules, which is extremely beneficial to broaden electrochemical stability window and improve the low-temperature ionic conductivity of the electrolyte (Fig. 2h). 3.3 Electrochemical performance of MSCs with HGEs at room temperature To determine the appropriate electrolyte and test conditions, we first conducted electrochemical measurements of the MSCs in different HGEs (the MSCs tested in EGy electrolyte were labeled as MSCs-y, y = 0, 2, 4, 5, 6) at room temperature (25 °C). Given the narrow electrochemical stability window and obvious polarization phenomenon observed from CV curves of MSCs-0 (Fig. 3 a), the operation voltage range of MSCs-0 was set as 0–1.2 V (Fig. S6). Relatively, MSCs-5 were measured with different cut-off voltages from 1.2 to 2.0 V as a representative example to determine test conditions of MSCs-y (y = 2, 4, 5, 6), comprehensively considering electrochemical stability and ionic conductivity of EG5. As shown in Fig. 3(b), the CV curves exhibited distinct electrochemical polarization in case of voltage exceeding 1.6 V, so the voltage window of MSCs-y (y = 2, 4, 5, 6) was set at 0–1.6 V. Based on this, the electrochemical characterizations including CV, galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) and EIS measurements were carried out to systematically evaluate MSCs-y (y = 2, 4, 5, 6). Notably, the different polarization degrees were observed from the CV curves and GCD profiles of MSCs-2 and MSCs-4 (Figs. S7 and S8). By contrast, MSCs-5 disclosed excellent electrical double-layer capacitive performance in the voltage range of 0–1.6 V, as seen from the almost rectangular CV curves (Fig. 3c) and symmetric triangular GCD profiles with negligible voltage drop (Fig. 3d). Further, the device gave out a high areal capacitance of 12.1 mF cm−2 and a high volumetric capacitance of 28.9 F cm−3 at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1, exceeding most aqueous carbon-based MSCs such as three-dimensional (3D) interconnected porous carbon based MSCs [42], MnO2-laser-induced-graphene (LIG) MSCs [43] and others [44,45]. In addition, superior rate performance was achieved with 65% capacitance retention even at a high scan rate of 200 mV s−1 compared to the value at 5 mV s−1 (Fig. 3f and Fig. S9a), attributed to closely-connected conductive network in microelectrodes and high ionic conductivity of EG5, which is in accordance with the EIS results (Fig. 3e). And the respective contributions of AC and FLG were compared by CV curves (Fig. S9b), which showed that the capacitance of MSCs-5 was mainly provided by AC. Although the MSCs-6 could also reach a high operating voltage of 0–1.6 V as same as MSCs-5, its availability is particularly poor at high scan rates (Figs. S10 and S11), derived from large viscosity and declined ionic conductivity of the electrolyte in case of excessive EG content. Consequently, the EG5 was selected as the optimal HGE taking into consideration of both voltage window and rate performance to further evaluate MSCs-5 in the following sections. It is also notable that MSCs-5 demonstrated long-term stable cyclability with a remarkable capacitance retention of 81.8% after 15,000 cycles at 1.5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 3g), suggestive of favorable reliability of our microdevices. Further, the MSCs-5 presented a high energy density of 10.3 mWh cm−3 at a power density of 115.6 mW cm−3 (Fig. 3h), superior to MSCs-0 (3.96 mWh cm−3 at 59.4 mW cm−3) and those previously reported energy storage devices such as commercial AC/AC supercapacitors (4.6 mWh cm−3 at 5521 mW cm−3) [46], B-doped LIG MSCs (4.2 mWh cm−3 at 559.3 mW cm−3) [47], graphene/NiOOH/Ni(OH)2 based MSCs (GNMSCs, 1.1 mWh cm−3 at 18.6 mW cm−3) [48], reduced graphene oxide/MnO2/silver nanowire (rGO/MnO2/AgNW) based MSCs (0.47mWh cm−3 at 93.1 mW cm−3) [49] and others [50,51], manifesting great significance of widened cell voltage. 3.4 Electrochemical performance of MSCs-5 at low temperature In order to verify the suitable working conditions of EG5 at low temperature, the solid-liquid phase transition characteristics of the electrolyte was investigated by differential scanning calorimeter (DSC). Fig. S12 shows the heat change of EG0 and EG5 in the range of −100–20 °C. It was found that the EG0 possessed a clear glass transition peak at −47.4 °C, which was due to the rapid glass transition. And glass transition temperature of EG5 was −62.8 °C [52]. This was attributed to the strong interaction between EG and water molecules [53], which inhibited the freezing process to enhance the performance of the HGEs at low temperatures. As discussed above, the introduction of EG additives effectively improved the anti-freezing properties of hybrid electrolyte, endowing huge possibilities to construct low-temperature MSCs, which are vitally important for practical applications. Therefore, we further tested the electrochemical performance of MSCs-5 at a wide temperature range (–30–10 °C) to demonstrate superior environmental adaption in device level (Fig. 4 a). As shown in Fig. 4(b and c) and Fig. S13(a), the MSCs-5 could maintain nearly ideal electrical double-layer capacitive behaviors from CV and GCD curves even under high scan rates and current densities at 0 °C. While the measurement temperature was set as low as −20 °C, the MSCs-5 have still displayed acceptable CV and GCD curves only with slight distortion (Fig. 4d and e, and Fig. S13b and c), implying favorable reliability of our microdevices at such a low temperature. Further, Fig. 4(f) showed the areal capacitance of MSCs-5 in the temperature range of −30–25 °C (Figs. S14–S17). More encouragingly, even at an ultralow temperature of −30 °C, the MSCs-5 have still delivered an areal capacitance of 8.3 mF cm−2, with 68.4% retention of the value at room temperature, indicating excellent low-temperature availability of our microdevices. In addition, MSCs-5 exhibited long-term stable cycling at −20 °C with an extraordinary capacitance retention of 84.5% after 15,000 cycles at 1.0 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4g) and capacitance retention of 85.7% after 15,000 cycles at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 at −30 °C (Fig. 4h), further demonstrating the reliability and great applicability of the MSCs. Simultaneously, in comparison to other supercapacitors at low temperature, it was found that MSCs-5 delivered better electrochemical performance than these devices in terms of energy density, power density and rate capability (Fig. S18). 3.5 Flexibility, integration and practicability of MSCs To satisfy the diversified requirements in actual applications, the multifunctionalities of MSCs such as mechanical flexibility and integration features were demonstrated to highlight the practicability of our devices. It is notable that all CV curves examined under different bending states remained almost coincident, showing slight capacitance fluctuation within the range of 2% (Fig. 5 a and b), indicative of outstanding flexibility and structural stability. Moreover, to realize the performance customization including high-voltage and large-capacitance output, MSCs arrays connected in serial and parallel (Fig. 5c) were fabricated by multi-step mask-assisted filtration method. It is worth mentioning that the interconnection of two adjacent electrodes were realized by direct filtration of overlapping AC and FLG films, which is a greatly extensible and simplified method without referring to any additional steps. As expected, both GCD profiles (Fig. 5d) and CV curves (Fig. S19a) showed a step-by-step increase in the working voltage from 1.6 V for one cell to 4.8 V for three cells and 8.0 V for five cells in serial connection, meanwhile the charge–discharge time maintained unchanged in GCD results (Fig. 5d), indicative of exceptional performance uniformity. This is also consistent with the monotonically increased equivalent series resistance (ESR) values from 11 Ω to 31 Ω and 53 Ω by increasing the number of serially connected cells (Fig. S19b). Furthermore, the current in CV curves (Fig. S19c) and discharge time in GCD profiles (Fig. 5e) of MSCs increased linearly from 1 to 5 cells in parallel, while the corresponding ESR values displayed almost inversely proportional decrease trend (Fig. S19d), accompanied with constant voltage, indicative of extensive applicability of our modularly integrated devices. In addition, to display the practicability of the MSCs in real scenarios, we prepared MSCs modules composed of three cells in series as shown in Fig. 5(f). After a series of deformation including bending (Fig. 5f), twisting (Fig. 5g), and winding (Fig. 5h and i), the microelectrodes didn’t separate from the substrates, further verifying excellent mechanical robustness. Moreover, the modular MSCs arrays successfully powered a light emitting diode (LED) and liquid crystal displays (LCDs) with logo and letter patterns (Fig. 5j–m), suggestive of excellent practicability of our microdevices. More surprisingly, the same application tests were also demonstrated at a sub-zero temperature (putting the devices in ice cubes), greatly highlighting reliability of our MSCs in extreme environments (Fig. 5n–p). 4 Conclusions In summary, we have developed a novel class of high-voltage and anti-freezing HGEs with low cost and high ionic conductivity through introducing EG into aqueous LiCl electrolytes. Because EG could partially break the hydrogen bonding network among water molecules in the electrolyte, voltage window of HGE is greatly widened to 2.7 V, and its anti-freezing property is dramatically improved, further boosting remarkable enhancement in energy density and low-temperature stability of the MSCs. Notably, our microdevices exhibit good mechanical flexibility, excellent module integration, outstanding performance uniformity and superior practicability. Moreover, this strategy is highly flexible and scalable to construct other anti-freezing microscale electrochemical energy storage devices through utilization of different electrodes and electrolytes, such as microscale lithium-ion batteries, to further improve energy density. Therefore, this work will pave a new avenue for the fabrication of flexible and anti-freezing microscale power sources towards smart electronics working at subzero temperatures. coredata.dc:description: Micro-supercapacitors (MSCs) are considered as highly competitive power sources for miniaturized electronics. However, narrow voltage window and poor anti-freezing properties of MSCs in conventional aqueous electrolytes lead to low energy density and limited environmental adaption. Herein, we report the construction of low-temperature and high-energy-density MSCs based on anti-freezing hybrid gel electrolytes (HGE) through introducing ethylene glycol (EG) additives into aqueous LiCl electrolyte. Since EG partially destroys hydrogen bond network among water molecules, the HGE exhibits maximum electrochemical stability window of 2.7 V and superior anti-freezing features with a glass transition temperature of −62.8 °C. Further, the optimized MSCs using activated carbon microelectrodes possess impressive volumetric capacitance of 28.9 F cm−3 and energy density of 10.3 mWh cm−3 in the voltage of 1.6 V, 2.6 times higher than MSCs tested in 1.2 V. Importantly, the MSCs display 68.3% capacitance retention even at −30 °C compared to the value at 25 °C, and ultra-long cyclability with 85.7% of initial capacitance after 15,000 times, indicating extraordinary low-temperature performance. Besides, our devices offer favorable flexibility and modular integration. Therefore, this work provides a general strategy of realizing flexible, safe and anti-freezing microscale power sources, holding great potential towards subzero-temperature microelectronic applications.
